advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, but nothing seems right in the picture...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Muffat</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special offer including italian books<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Here are the 20 questions :-)<br><font color="#666666"> If you're looking for your first home computer, may we make a suggestion.<br> Tear out this page.<br> And ask these questions of every computer you look at.<br> 1) Is the basic price reason­able, say under £180?<br> 2) Does it work with a monitor as well as with an ordinary UHF TV?<br> 3) Does it include a basic training manual that doesn't require a science degree to understand?<br> 4) Does it have colour?<br> 5) And sound?<br> 6) Does it take cassettes?<br> 7) And cartridges?<br> 8) And can you operate them with joysticks working directly off the basic unit?<br> 9) Does it have a profes­sional quality keyboard that's guaranteed for twenty million de­pressions (and no headaches)?<br> 10) Does it have colour graphics that are capable of producing detailed pictures?<br> 11) Is the case robust enough to stand up to the kids?<br> ­12) Does it use a standard language that's not a million, miles away from English?<br> 13) Is there an expanding range of high quality sofrware available from the makers?<br> 14) Does the software in­clude educational programs for adults as well as the very young?<br> 15) And is there sofrware sophisticated enough to satisfy the experts?<br> 16) Does it use the most up to date technology, for instance the 6809E microprocessor?<br> 17) Will it drive a standard printer directly from the basic unit?<br> 18) Is it made in the UK?<br> 19) And for the basic price will I get an easily accessible, yet large memory of at least 32K?<br> 20) Or willI have to add lots of extras (and lots of money for that much?<br> After you've finished pester­ing every computer salesman in sight, compare your answers to these, Courtesy of the Dragon 32 (this is,after all, an ad for the Dragon)<br> Questions 1-19. Yes,yes,yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes and yes.<br> Question 20. No.<br> If you're thinking that that's a lot of computer for the money. you'd be right.<br> However, when you come to read the handbook you'll soon realise that somethings missing. The jargon usually asso­ciated with computers.<br> You see every part of the Dragon has been carefully designed to be easily under­stood,even by total beginners. Yet it has all the features an expert could want Just ask it. </font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The ZX-81 will soon become a precious work tool"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, although a little excessive.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Micromachine 4000 but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted for reference...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHRISTMAS 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"><b> A smart investment</b><br> Radio Shack's popular TRS-80 Color Computer is now on sale. You can get this complete, versatile system with a 16 K-byte memory and Standard Color BASIC language for only $299.95 (Cat. No. 26-3004, reg. $399.95). It's the affordable way for the entire family to start computing.</font><br><br> The Extended BASIC - 16 KB version was priced $399.95<br> The 32 KB version was priced $549.95.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is one of the first adverts showing a one computer dedicated software range. In 1979, the computer manufacturers understood that it was not enough any more to sell hardware and that the success of a computer depended now on the range and quality of the software that came with it.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The simple fact is nobody - nobody in the personal computer industry - offers more software than Ohio Scientific! Right now, as you read this, Ohio Scientific has just about 2 million bytes of software available for our C4P MF computer.</font> <br><br> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> adds:<br><font color="#666666"> I'd like to mention that Aardvark Software in Michigan was one of the better vendors of software for the C4P games.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #5 </strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> During Jacquard's early years, as a "system house", the company developed communications and peripheral devices that were not available from any other sources. Some of these are still available only from Jacquard. <br><br> Through these devices, Jacquard acquired hardware design and production skills, thus becoming experienced in integrating 'pieces' into systems that worked, and worked well. <br><br> These years of experience enabled Jacquard to design the first truly affordable and multi-functional small business system - the Jacquard Videocomputer... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: 2 x 5.25'' disk-drives (800KB and 128 KB single side)
computer.description:
The Agat-9, produced after the Agat, was a fully compatible Apple II+ system with real expansion possibilities (6 non-apple compatible slots).
It was then possible to add memory expansion cards, serial cards, additional disk-drives and even network cards.
In fact the Agat-9 was also compatible with the more exotic Pravetz-8 and Tzyntzy computers, which were also Apple II clones.
computer.graphics: 512 x 256, 256 x 256 (monochrome), 256 x 256 (4 colors), 128 x 128 (16 colors), 280 x 192 (2 colors)
computer.media: 2 x 5.25'' disk-drives (800KB and 128 KB single side)
computer.name: Agat 9
computer.peripherals: RAM expansion board, printer card, network card, analog/digital card,...
